Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Modeling and Optimization of Manufacturing Variability and Product Reliability for Advanced and Evolving Technologies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop integrated quality and reliability models and analysis tools that provide fundamental insights for the successful development and commercialization of evolving technologies, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) and biomedical implant devices. For many new and evolving technologies, their continued successful development depends on the concurrent modeling and optimization of process variability and product life, which are inherently linked for many of these technologies. The first research effort is to develop an integrated quantitative methodology to jointly optimize system quality and reliability. Based on this integrated framework, probabilistic models will be investigated for predicting reliability of devices that experience multiple failure processes due to simultaneous exposure to degradation and shock loads. Competing risk models with dependent failure processes will be developed and extended. In addition, reliability models will be developed for complex systems with multiple independent or dependent components. Multiple user objectives (e.g., quality, reliability, yield, cost, etc.) will be simultaneously considered by the formulation and solution of multi-objective optimization problems. Finally, the developed models will be validated for MEMS and biomedical implant devices through collaborations with industrial and government partners.

The results of this research will advance the state-of-the-art by contributing new concepts, models and algorithms. A solid multidisciplinary scientific foundation will be built to combine methodologies in quality, reliability, statistics and operations research. In addition, the success of this research will offer fundamental insights that can be transformed to many newer design and manufacturing problems, such as nano-technology that also has unique manufacturing challenges. The integrated methodology can provide timely and effective tools for decision-makers in manufacturing to economically optimize operational decisions for improving reliability, quality and productivity. Undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups will be continuously recruited to work on this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this award is to develop integrated quality and reliability models and analysis tools that provide fundamental insights for the successful development and commercialization of evolving technologies, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) and biomedical implant devices. For many new and evolving technologies, their continued successful development depends on the concurrent modeling and optimization of process variability and product life, which are inherently linked for many of these technologies.

Intellectual Merit - The successful implementation of the five tasks in this research has: (1) provided a solid multidisciplinary scientific foundation to combine methodologies in quality, reliability, statistics and operations research that can be extended and applied for different disciplines and applications, (2) advanced the state-of-the-art on evolving technologies by contributing new concepts, models and algorithms, and (3) offered fundamental insights that can be transformed to many newer design and manufacturing problems, such as nano-technology that have unique manufacturing challenges. The integrated methodology can provide timely and effective tools for decision-makers in manufacturing to economically optimize operational decisions for improving reliability, quality and productivity. The research outcomes and findings from each task are summarized as follows:

(1) The first research effort was to develop an integrated quantitative methodology to jointly optimize system quality and reliability. This study proposed mathematical models to jointly determine burn-in, inspection and preventive replacement policies for micro-machined micro-engines subject to wear degradation, which is a major failure mechanism in MEMS devices. (2) Based on this integrated framework, various probabilistic models have been investigated for analyzing reliability of devices that experience multiple dependent competing failure processes (MDCFP) due to simultaneous exposure to degradation and shock loads. Competing risk models have been developed and implemented for micro-engines and stents, considering different aspects of dependence among MDCFP based on their physics-of-failure mechanisms. (3) Reliability models have been developed for complex systems with multiple independent or dependent components. For a multi-component system, we considered different component shock sets according to shock sizes, functions and acting positions. We also studied a complex system with dependent components subject to respective degradation processes, and the dependency among components is established via environmental factors. (4) Multiple user objectives (e.g., quality, reliability, yield, cost, etc.) were simultaneously considered by the formulation and solution of multi-objective optimization problems. For a system subject to MDCFP, a multiple objective optimization formulation was proposed and solved to provide a realistic approach to maximize the repairable system availability when the maintenance cost is minimized. (5) Finally, we conducted the accelerated fatigue test for stent materials through collaborations with industrial partners, which provided us data, images and process knowledge on fatigue crack growth of biomedical implant materials.

The next stage of advancement requires the manufacturing process to be high-yield, low-cost and highly-reliable. The models and analytical tools developed in this research have contributed to address these new challenges, by contributing new concepts, models and algorithms.
